title: The TCP/IP Model - Understanding the Internet Protocol Suite
description: Master the TCP/IP model through comprehensive practice covering all four layers, protocol mapping, OSI comparison, encapsulation process, and real-world troubleshooting scenarios.
starterCode:
# TCP/IP Model Complete Exercise - Based on Lesson 007
# Covers all 4 TCP/IP layers and their relationship to OSI

## SECTION 1: TCP/IP Model Overview

# Number of layers in TCP/IP model: ___
# Number of layers in OSI model: ___

# TCP/IP also known as:
# 1. Internet Protocol ___
# 2. ___ model (Department of Defense)

# TCP/IP model characteristics:
# Focus: ___ (implementation/conceptual)
# Development: Based on ___ protocols in use
# Adoption: ___ standard
# Layers: ___ than OSI (fewer/more)

# Key differences from OSI:
# - TCP/IP is ___-focused
# - OSI is ___-focused
# - TCP/IP reflects ___ networking
# - OSI is protocol-___


## SECTION 2: Four TCP/IP Layers

# List the 4 TCP/IP layers from top to bottom:
# Layer 4: ___ Layer
# Layer 3: ___ Layer
# Layer 2: ___ Layer
# Layer 1: Network ___ Layer (also called ___ Layer)

# Alternative name for Layer 1:
# - Network ___ Layer
# - ___ Layer


## SECTION 3: Layer Mapping - TCP/IP to OSI

# TCP/IP Application Layer = OSI Layers ___, ___, ___
# TCP/IP Transport Layer = OSI Layer ___
# TCP/IP Internet Layer = OSI Layer ___
# TCP/IP Network Access Layer = OSI Layers ___, ___

# Which TCP/IP layer combines the most OSI layers?
# Answer: ___ Layer (combines ___ OSI layers)

# Which TCP/IP layer maps 1:1 to OSI?
# Answer: ___ Layer = OSI Layer ___

# Remove IP ___, pass to Transport

# Step 4 - Transport:
# Check ___ number (which application?)
# Reorder ___ (TCP only)
# Remove header, pass to ___

# Step 5 - Application:
# Process ___

solution:
# TCP/IP Model Complete Exercise - COMPLETE SOLUTION

## SECTION 1: TCP/IP Model Overview

# Number of layers in TCP/IP model: 4
# Number of layers in OSI model: 7

# TCP/IP also known as:
# 1. Internet Protocol Suite
# 2. DoD model (Department of Defense)

# TCP/IP model characteristics:
# Focus: Implementation (implementation/conceptual)
# Development: Based on actual protocols in use
# Adoption: Universal standard
# Layers: Fewer than OSI (fewer/more)

# Key differences from OSI:
# - TCP/IP is implementation-focused
# - OSI is conceptual-focused
# - TCP/IP reflects real-world networking
# - OSI is protocol-independent


## SECTION 2: Four TCP/IP Layers

# List the 4 TCP/IP layers from top to bottom:
# Layer 4: Application Layer
# Layer 3: Transport Layer
# Layer 2: Internet Layer
# Layer 1: Network Access Layer (also called Link Layer)

# Alternative name for Layer 1:
# - Network Interface Layer
# - Link Layer


## SECTION 3: Layer Mapping - TCP/IP to OSI

# TCP/IP Application Layer = OSI Layers 5, 6, 7
# TCP/IP Transport Layer = OSI Layer 4
# TCP/IP Internet Layer = OSI Layer 3
# TCP/IP Network Access Layer = OSI Layers 1, 2

# Which TCP/IP layer combines the most OSI layers?
# Answer: Application Layer (combines 3 OSI layers)

# Which TCP/IP layer maps 1:1 to OSI?
# Answer: Transport Layer = OSI Layer 4


## SECTION 4: Network Access Layer (Layer 1)

# Combines which OSI layers?
# Answer: OSI Layer 1 (Physical) and Layer 2 (Data Link)

# Five key responsibilities:
# 1. Physical transmission
# 2. Framing
# 3. MAC addressing
# 4. Media access control
# 5. Error detection

# Physical transmission includes:
# - Electrical signals
# - Radio waves
# - Light (fiber optics)
# - Cable specifications


## SECTION 5: Network Access Technologies

# Ethernet:
# Standard: IEEE 802.3
# Address type: MAC addresses (48-bit)
# Access method: CSMA/CD (historical)
# Modern mode: Full-duplex
# Speed range: 10 Mbps to 400 Gbps

# Wi-Fi:
# Type: Wireless LAN (WLAN)
# Standard: IEEE 802.11
# Standards: 802.11a, b, g, n, ac, ax
# Access method: CSMA/CA
# Frequency bands: 2.4 GHz, 5 GHz, 6 GHz

# PPP:
# Full name: Point-to-Point Protocol
# Use: WAN connections
# Examples: Dial-up, DSL
# Authentication: PAP, CHAP

# HDLC:
# Full name: High-Level Data Link Control
# Type: Synchronous serial connections
# Used by: Cisco default on serial interfaces


## SECTION 6: Network Access Layer Functions

# MAC Addressing:
# Length: 48 bits (6 bytes)
# Format: XX:XX:XX:XX:XX:XX (hexadecimal)
# Also called: Burned-in Address (BIA)
# Resolution: ARP resolves IP to MAC

# Error Detection:
# Method: Frame Check Sequence (FCS)
# Algorithm: CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Check)
# Action: Corrupted frames are discarded

# Frame Delimiting:
# Purpose: Identify frame boundaries
# Components: Preamble and SFD (Start Frame Delimiter)
# Markers: Start and end markers


## SECTION 7: Internet Layer (Layer 2)

# Equivalent to which OSI layer?
# Answer: OSI Layer 3 (Network)

# Four key responsibilities:
# 1. Logical addressing (IP addresses)
# 2. Routing
# 3. Packet encapsulation
# 4. Best-effort delivery

# Addressing:
# IPv4: 32-bit addresses
# IPv6: 128-bit addresses
# Structure: Network and host portions

# Delivery type:
# Connection: Connectionless (connectionless/connection-oriented)
# Reliability: No (no guarantees)
# Handled by: Transport layer provides reliability


## SECTION 8: Internet Layer Protocols

# IP (Internet Protocol):
# IPv4 addresses: 4.3 billion possible
# IPv6 addresses: Virtually unlimited
# Field: TTL (Time to Live)
# Purpose: Prevents loops

# ICMP:
# Full name: Internet Control Message Protocol
# Use: Error reporting and diagnostics
# Tools: Ping (Echo Request/Reply)
# Tools: Traceroute (Time Exceeded)
# Messages: Destination Unreachable
# Data transfer: No (yes/no)

# ARP:
# Full name: Address Resolution Protocol
# Resolves: IP addresses to MAC addresses
# Method: Broadcasts "Who has IP x.x.x.x?"
# Stores: ARP cache
# Layer: 2.5 (between Internet and Network Access)

# IGMP:
# Full name: Internet Group Management Protocol
# Manages: Multicast group membership
# Used by: Routers to track listeners
# Versions: IGMPv1, v2, v3


## SECTION 9: Routing Protocols

# RIP:
# Full name: Routing Information Protocol
# Type: Distance-vector
# Metric: Hop count

# OSPF:
# Full name: Open Shortest Path First
# Type: Link-state
# Metric: Cost

# EIGRP:
# Full name: Enhanced Interior Gateway Routing Protocol
# Vendor: Cisco
# Type: Hybrid (hybrid)

# BGP:
# Full name: Border Gateway Protocol
# Use: Internet backbone routing
# Type: Exterior gateway protocol (EGP)


## SECTION 10: IPv4 Packet Structure

# Key fields in IPv4 header:
# - Version: Always 4 for IPv4
# - IHL: Internet Header Length
# - ToS: Type of Service
# - Total Length: Entire packet size
# - TTL: Time to Live
# - Protocol: Upper layer protocol (6=TCP, 17=UDP)
# - Header Checksum: Error detection
# - Source IP Address
# - Destination IP Address


## SECTION 11: Routing Process

# Six steps in routing a packet:
# 1. Receive packet from Transport layer
# 2. Examine destination IP address
# 3. Consult routing table
# 4. Determine next-hop or delivery interface
# 5. Decrement TTL by 1
# 6. Recalculate header checksum
# 7. Pass to Network Access layer

# What happens if TTL reaches 0?
# Answer: Packet is dropped and ICMP Time Exceeded sent back


## SECTION 12: Transport Layer (Layer 3)

# Identical to which OSI layer?
# Answer: OSI Layer 4 (Transport)

# Five key responsibilities:
# 1. Segmentation
# 2. Connection management
# 3. Reliability (TCP only)
# 4. Flow control
# 5. Multiplexing

# Segmentation:
# Purpose: Break data into manageable segments
# Adds: Sequence numbers

# Multiplexing:
# Method: Port numbers identify applications
# Benefit: Multiple concurrent connections


## SECTION 13: TCP vs UDP

# TCP characteristics:
# Connection: Connection-oriented
# Reliability: Yes (yes/no)
# Delivery: Ordered delivery
# Handshake: Three-way handshake
# Control: Flow control and congestion control
# Overhead: Higher (higher/lower)

# UDP characteristics:
# Connection: Connectionless
# Reliability: Unreliable (best-effort)
# Delivery: No guarantee of delivery
# Handshake: No (yes/no)
# Overhead: Lower (higher/lower)
# Speed: Faster than TCP

# TCP used by:
# - HTTP (web browsing)
# - HTTPS (secure web)
# - FTP (file transfer)
# - SSH (secure shell)
# - Email: SMTP, POP3, IMAP

# UDP used by:
# - DNS (name resolution)
# - DHCP (IP addressing)
# - VoIP (voice/video)
# - Streaming
# - Online gaming


## SECTION 14: Port Number Ranges

# Well-Known Ports:
# Range: 0 to 1023
# Use: Standard services
# Permission: Require administrative privileges
# Examples: 80 (HTTP), 443 (HTTPS), 22 (SSH)

# Registered Ports:
# Range: 1024 to 49151
# Registration: With IANA
# Use: Vendor-specific applications
# Examples: 3306 (MySQL), 3389 (RDP)

# Dynamic/Private Ports:
# Range: 49152 to 65535
# Also called: Ephemeral ports
# Use: Temporary client-side ports
# Assigned by: OS


## SECTION 15: Application Layer (Layer 4)

# Combines which OSI layers?
# Answer: OSI Layers 5, 6, 7 (Session, Presentation, Application)

# Four key responsibilities:
# 1. Application services
# 2. Protocol functions
# 3. Data formatting
# 4. Session management

# Application Services:
# - Network process to application
# - User interface
# - Data representation


## SECTION 16: Application Layer Protocol Categories

# Web Services:
# - HTTP/HTTPS: Web browsing
# - WebSocket: Real-time bidirectional
# - REST APIs: Web services

# File Transfer:
# - FTP/FTPS: Traditional file transfer
# - SFTP: SSH-based file transfer
# - TFTP: Simple, lightweight (UDP)

# Email:
# - SMTP: Sending email
# - POP3/IMAP: Receiving email
# - MIME: Multimedia email extensions

# Network Services:
# - DNS: Name resolution
# - DHCP: Dynamic IP addressing
# - NTP: Time synchronization
# - SNMP: Network management

# Remote Access:
# - SSH: Secure remote access
# - Telnet: Insecure remote access (legacy)
# - RDP: Remote desktop
# - VNC: Virtual network computing

# Directory Services:
# - LDAP: Directory access
# - Kerberos: Authentication
# - RADIUS/TACACS+: AAA


## SECTION 17: Why Both OSI and TCP/IP?

# OSI Model value:
# - Comprehensive theoretical framework
# - Educational tool
# - Troubleshooting methodology
# - Vendor-neutral terminology

# TCP/IP Model value:
# - Reflects actual implementations
# - Internet standard
# - Simpler, more practical
# - Universal adoption

# In practice:
# - Use OSI for conceptual discussions
# - Use TCP/IP for actual protocol implementation
# - Both models coexist and complement each other


## SECTION 18: TCP/IP Advantages

# Historical advantages:
# - ARPANET adoption (1970s)
# - Military and academic use
# - Open standards
# - Free implementations

# Technical advantages:
# - Flexibility
# - Scalability
# - Interoperability
# - Proven reliability

# Why TCP/IP won over OSI:
# - Historical (ARPANET success)
# - Internet growth
# - Universal adoption
# - Vendor support


## SECTION 19: TCP/IP Limitations

# IPv4 address exhaustion:
# Problem: Only 4.3 billion addresses
# Solutions:
# - IPv6 (128-bit addresses)
# - NAT (Network Address Translation)
# - CIDR (Classless Inter-Domain Routing)

# Security:
# Original: Not designed with security in mind
# Added later:
# - IPsec (IP security)
# - TLS (Transport Layer Security)
# - SSH (Secure Shell)

# QoS challenges:
# Issue: Best-effort delivery
# Solutions:
# - DiffServ (Differentiated Services)
# - MPLS (Multi-Protocol Label Switching)

# Complexity:
# Challenge: Many protocols and options
# Requirement: Expertise to manage


## SECTION 20: Data Encapsulation in TCP/IP

# Encapsulation process (sending):

# Step 1 - Application Layer:
# Generates: Data
# Example: HTTP GET request

# Step 2 - Transport Layer:
# Adds: TCP or UDP header
# Includes: Source/destination ports
# Creates: Segment (TCP) or Datagram (UDP)

# Step 3 - Internet Layer:
# Adds: IP header
# Includes: Source/destination IP addresses
# Includes: TTL (Time to Live)
# Creates: Packet

# Step 4 - Network Access Layer:
# Adds: Frame header and trailer
# Includes: Source/destination MAC addresses
# Includes: FCS (Frame Check Sequence)
# Creates: Frame
# Transmitted as: Bits


## SECTION 21: Protocol Data Units (PDUs)

# Match layer to PDU:
# Application Layer: Data
# Transport Layer: Segment (TCP) or Datagram (UDP)
# Internet Layer: Packet
# Network Access Layer: Frame
# Physical: Bits (on wire)


## SECTION 22: De-encapsulation Process

# Reverse process (receiving):

# Step 1 - Physical:
# Receive bits, convert to frame

# Step 2 - Network Access:
# Check FCS (error detection)
# Remove frame header, extract packet

# Step 3 - Internet:
# Read destination IP (is it for me?)
# Remove IP header, pass to Transport

# Step 4 - Transport:
# Check port number (which application?)
# Reorder segments (TCP only)
# Remove header, pass to Application

# Step 5 - Application:
# Process data


## SECTION 23: Real-World Example Part 1 - DNS
# User browses to https://example.com

# DNS Resolution:
# Application: Browser needs IP for example.com
# Transport: DNS query sent using UDP protocol
# Port: UDP port 53
# Internet: Packet routed to DNS server
# Response: DNS server responds with IP: 93.184.216.34


## SECTION 24: Real-World Example Part 2 - TCP Connection

# TCP three-way handshake:
# Step 1: Client sends SYN to port 443
# Step 2: Server responds with SYN-ACK
# Step 3: Client sends ACK
# Result: Connection established


## SECTION 25: Real-World Example Part 3 - TLS

# TLS handshake (Application Layer):
# Step 1: Negotiate encryption
# Step 2: Verify server certificate
# Step 3: Establish secure session


## SECTION 26: Real-World Example Part 4 - HTTP Request

# HTTP request:
# Application: GET /index.html HTTP/1.1
# Transport: Create TCP segments
# Internet: Create IP packets with source/dest IPs
# Network Access: Create frames with MAC addresses


## SECTION 27: Real-World Example Part 5 - Routing

# Routing across Internet:
# Each router:
# 1. Removes old frame
# 2. Reads destination IP address
# 3. Consults routing table
# 4. Creates new frame with next-hop MAC
# 5. Decrements TTL
# 6. Forwards to next hop


## SECTION 28: Troubleshooting by Layer

# Network Access Layer troubleshooting:
# Check:
# - Cables and connectors
# - Link lights (LEDs)
# - Switch port configuration
# - Physical damage
# Tools: ip link, ethtool, LED indicators

# Internet Layer troubleshooting:
# Check:
# - IP configuration
# - Routing tables
# - Network connectivity
# Tools: ip addr, route -n, ping, traceroute

# Transport Layer troubleshooting:
# Check:
# - Listening ports
# - Firewall rules
# - Port connectivity
# Tools: netstat, ss, telnet <host> <port>, nc

# Application Layer troubleshooting:
# Check:
# - Application configuration
# - Service status
# - Application logs
# Test: Protocol-specific commands


## SECTION 29: Common TCP/IP Protocols by Layer

# Network Access Layer:
# - Ethernet
# - Wi-Fi (IEEE 802.11)
# - PPP
# - HDLC

# Internet Layer:
# - IP (routing)
# - ICMP (diagnostics)
# - ARP (IP to MAC)
# - IGMP (multicast)

# Transport Layer:
# - TCP (reliable)
# - UDP (fast)

# Application Layer:
# - HTTP/HTTPS
# - FTP/SFTP
# - SMTP/POP3/IMAP
# - DNS/DHCP


## SECTION 30: Application Protocol Ports Summary

# Fill in port numbers:
# HTTP: 80
# HTTPS: 443
# FTP: 20, 21
# SSH/SFTP: 22
# Telnet: 23
# SMTP: 25, 587
# DNS: 53
# DHCP: 67, 68
# TFTP: 69
# POP3: 110
# NTP: 123
# IMAP: 143
# SNMP: 161, 162
# LDAP: 389
# RDP: 3389


## SECTION 31: Protocol Selection Scenario 1
# Need reliable file transfer

# Question 1: Which transport protocol?
# Answer: TCP (connection-oriented, reliable)

# Question 2: Which application protocol?
# Answer: FTP or FTPS or SFTP

# Question 3: Why not UDP?
# Answer: UDP is unreliable (no guaranteed delivery)


## SECTION 32: Protocol Selection Scenario 2
# Need fast, real-time video streaming

# Question 1: Which transport protocol?
# Answer: UDP (low overhead, fast)

# Question 2: Why not TCP?
# Answer: TCP adds latency (retransmissions cause delay)

# Question 3: Trade-off?
# Answer: Unreliable delivery but better real-time performance


## SECTION 33: Protocol Selection Scenario 3
# Need to query DNS server

# Question 1: Which transport protocol?
# Answer: UDP (small queries, fast)

# Question 2: Port number?
# Answer: 53

# Question 3: Backup if UDP fails?
# Answer: TCP (for large responses or zone transfers)


## SECTION 34: Encapsulation Scenario
# Web browser sends HTTP GET request

# At Application Layer:
# Data: "GET /page.html HTTP/1.1"

# At Transport Layer:
# Added: TCP header with source port 50000 (ephemeral), dest port 80
# PDU: Segment

# At Internet Layer:
# Added: IP header with source IP 192.168.1.100, dest IP 93.184.216.34
# PDU: Packet

# At Network Access Layer:
# Added: Ethernet header with source MAC, dest MAC
# Added: FCS trailer
# PDU: Frame


## SECTION 35: OSI vs TCP/IP Summary Table

# Complete the comparison:

# Number of layers:
# OSI: 7
# TCP/IP: 4

# Development approach:
# OSI: Conceptual (conceptual/practical)
# TCP/IP: Practical (conceptual/practical)

# Adoption:
# OSI: Reference model
# TCP/IP: Implementation standard

# Upper layers:
# OSI: Separate Session, Presentation, Application
# TCP/IP: Combined Application layer

# Lower layers:
# OSI: Separate Physical and Data Link
# TCP/IP: Combined Network Access layer


## SECTION 36: Layer Responsibility Summary

# Network Access Layer handles:
# - Physical transmission
# - MAC addressing
# - Frame delimiting

# Internet Layer handles:
# - Logical addressing (IP)
# - Routing
# - Best-effort delivery

# Transport Layer handles:
# - End-to-end communication
# - Reliability
# - Flow control (TCP)

# Application Layer handles:
# - Application services
# - Data formatting
# - User interface


## SECTION 37: When to Use Which Model?

# Use OSI model for:
# - Conceptual discussions
# - Education
# - Vendor-neutral terminology
# - Troubleshooting methodology

# Use TCP/IP model for:
# - Actual protocol implementation
# - Internet standards
# - Protocol selection
# - Real-world networking


## SECTION 38: Critical Protocol Functions

# ARP function:
# Resolves IP to MAC
# Method: Broadcast
# Cache: ARP cache

# ICMP function:
# Type: Error messages
# Tools: Ping and traceroute
# Not for: Data transfer

# DHCP function:
# Provides: Dynamic IP addresses
# Process: DORA (4 steps)
# Ports: 67 (server), 68 (client)

# DNS function:
# Resolves: Domain names to IP addresses
# Structure: Hierarchical, distributed
# Port: 53


## SECTION 39: TCP Reliability Mechanisms

# How TCP ensures reliability:
# 1. Three-way handshake
# 2. Sequence numbers
# 3. Acknowledgments
# 4. Retransmissions
# 5. Flow control
# 6. Congestion control


## SECTION 40: FINAL REVIEW

# Question 1: Four TCP/IP layers?
# 1. Application
# 2. Transport
# 3. Internet
# 4. Network Access

# Question 2: TCP vs UDP key difference?
# TCP: Connection-oriented, reliable, ordered delivery
# UDP: Connectionless, unreliable, fast, low overhead

# Question 3: What does each layer add during encapsulation?
# Transport: Port numbers (creates segment/datagram)
# Internet: IP addresses (creates packet)
# Network Access: MAC addresses and FCS (creates frame)

# Question 4: PDU at each layer?
# Application: Data
# Transport: Segment (TCP) or Datagram (UDP)
# Internet: Packet
# Network Access: Frame

# Question 5: Which protocols at Internet Layer?
# 1. IP (routing)
# 2. ICMP (diagnostics)
# 3. ARP (IP to MAC resolution)
# 4. IGMP (multicast management)

# Question 6: Why use TCP/IP model instead of OSI?
# Answer: TCP/IP is implementation-focused, simpler (4 vs 7 layers), reflects real-world protocols, universal Internet standard, proven in practice

# Question 7: What layer handles MAC addresses?
# Answer: Network Access Layer (combines OSI Physical and Data Link)

# Question 8: What layer handles IP addresses?
# Answer: Internet Layer (equivalent to OSI Network Layer)
hints: TCP/IP has 4 layers vs OSI's 7 layers; it's implementation-focused and forms the Internet standard
Layer mapping: Application (OSI 5-7), Transport (OSI 4), Internet (OSI 3), Network Access (OSI 1-2)
Network Access Layer: Handles physical transmission, MAC addressing, framing, error detection (Ethernet, Wi-Fi)
Internet Layer: Handles logical addressing (IP), routing, best-effort delivery; protocols include IP, ICMP, ARP, IGMP
Transport Layer: TCP (reliable, connection-oriented) vs UDP (fast, connectionless, unreliable)
Application Layer: Combines OSI layers 5-7; includes HTTP, FTP, SMTP, DNS, DHCP, SSH
Encapsulation: Application Data → Transport Segment → Internet Packet → Network Access Frame → Physical Bits
PDUs by layer: Data (Application), Segment/Datagram (Transport), Packet (Internet), Frame (Network Access), Bits (Physical)
ARP resolves IP to MAC addresses; ICMP provides error messages and diagnostics (ping, traceroute)
DHCP DORA: Discover, Offer, Request, Acknowledge; provides dynamic IP addressing
TCP reliability: Three-way handshake, sequence numbers, acknowledgments, retransmissions, flow control
De-encapsulation: Reverse process - remove headers at each layer as data moves up the stack
Routing process: Examine dest IP, consult routing table, decrement TTL, recalculate checksum, forward
Use TCP for reliable transfers (HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, SSH, email); UDP for speed (DNS, DHCP, VoIP, streaming)
TCP/IP advantages: Based on ARPANET, open standards, flexible, scalable, universal Internet adoption
IPv4 limitations: Address exhaustion (4.3 billion); solutions include IPv6, NAT, CIDR
Troubleshooting: Check cables/LEDs (Network Access), IP config/routing (Internet), ports/firewall (Transport), app config (Application)
OSI is theoretical/educational; TCP/IP is practical/implementation; both models complement each other

testCases.description: Knows TCP/IP has 4 layers: Application, Transport, Internet, Network Access
testCases.validation: assert '4' in code or 'four' in code.lower()

testCases.description: Understands layer mapping between TCP/IP and OSI
testCases.validation: assert 'application' in code.lower() and 'transport' in code.lower() and 'internet' in code.lower()

testCases.description: Knows TCP is reliable and connection-oriented, UDP is fast and connectionless
testCases.validation: assert 'tcp' in code.lower() or 'udp' in code.lower()

testCases.description: Understands encapsulation process and PDUs at each layer
testCases.validation: assert 'segment' in code.lower() or 'packet' in code.lower() or 'frame' in code.lower()

testCases.description: Knows Internet Layer protocols (IP, ICMP, ARP, IGMP)
testCases.validation: assert 'ip' in code.lower() or 'icmp' in code.lower() or 'arp' in code.lower()

testCases.description: Understands ARP resolves IP to MAC addresses
testCases.validation: assert 'arp' in code.lower() and ('mac' in code.lower() or 'ip' in code.lower())

testCases.description: Knows DHCP uses DORA process (Discover, Offer, Request, Acknowledge)
testCases.validation: assert 'dhcp' in code.lower() or 'dora' in code.lower()

testCases.description: Identifies Network Access Layer handles MAC addresses, Internet Layer handles IP
testCases.validation: assert 'network access' in code.lower() or 'internet' in code.lower()

testCases.description: Understands TCP/IP is implementation-focused, OSI is conceptual
testCases.validation: assert 'implementation' in code.lower() or 'practical' in code.lower() or 'conceptual' in code.lower()

testCases.description: Knows routing process includes TTL decrement and routing table lookup
testCases.validation: assert 'ttl' in code.lower() or 'routing' in code.lower() or 'route' in code.lower()
